Feminism's Timeline

Click on a category to see main events

Click on a category to see the main events
  • The first American women’s right convention, the Seneca Falls, was held.
  • The international women’s day started to be celebrated worldwide.
  • Conferences feminism-related begin to being held worldwide.
  • The expressions “First wave of feminism” and “Second wave of feminism” were coined.
  • The slogan “sisterhood is powerful” was used for the first time.
  • Turkish feminist Şenal Sarıhan shared the Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights Award.
  • Scandal misogyny-related gave media attention to the feminist problem worldwide.
  • In different countries some jobs were specifically opened to women.
  • Women started to have the right to stand for election, although with some restrinctions.
  • The topic of equal payment for male and female jobs started to be discussed.
  • Margaret Thatcher became the first female Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
  • Women started to held important job position in different countries worldwide.
  • Most of the countries worldwide granted to women the right to vote.
  • In some countries divorce was legalized.
  • Most of the countries worldwide granted economic rights, as the owning of properties, the admission to have a will and the possibility to have a separate economy.
  • Most of the countries started to make laws to end discrimination and spread equality.
  • Some countries granted rights related to maternity: such as maternity leave, contracception, childcare and abortion.
  • A few countries started to make law to end violence against women.
  • Some countries granted rights to end violence against women.
  • Some countries made laws to end discrimination and spread equality.
  • In Argentina the newspaper La Voz de la Mujer was published for the first time.
  • Dionísia Gonçalves Pinto, brazilian, published her first book.
  • In Denmark "Clara Raphael, Twelve Letters" by Mathilde Fibiger was published.
  • In England was set the first suffragette newspaper: Votes for women.
  • In South Africa: Olive Schreiner published Women and Labor.
  • American feminist Susan Brownmiller published the landmark book Against Our Will, about rape.
  • Sisterhood Is Powerful, An Anthology of Writings from the Women's Liberation Movement was published.
  • American feminist Valerie Solanas wrote and published SCUM Manifesto.
  • American feminist Kate Millett published her book, Sexual Politics.
  • The song "I Am Woman" was published, which became an enduring anthem for the women's liberation movement.
  • The feminist art piece The Dinner Party, by American feminist artist Judy Chicago, was first put on display at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.
  • Susan Faludi publishes Backlash: The Undeclared War Against American Women.
  • Publication of Jennifer Baumgardner and Amy Richards, Manifesta: Young Women, Feminism, and the Future.
  • Start of Feministing blog by Jessica Valenti and Vanessa Valenti.
  • Release of the film Thelma and Louise.
  • First edition of the magazine Bitch: Feminist Response to Pop Culture appears.
  • Publication of Naomi Wolf, The Beauty Myth.
  • Emma Sulkowicz begins the Mattress Performance (Carry That Weight) to highlight campus sexual assault.
  • Anita Sarkeesian launches Tropes vs. Women in Video Games.
  • Laura Bates creates the Everyday Sexism Project for women to report sexist encounters.
  • Release of the video “10 Hours of Walking in NYC as a Woman”.
  • The Feminist Center was founded in Argentina.
  • The New South Wales Womanhood Suffrage League was founded in Australia.
  • The National Federation of Women Workers, the East London Federation of Suffragettes, the Six point group, the women’s freedom leagued the women’s social and political union were founded in England.
  • The Danish Women's Society was founded in Denmark
  • Chicana feminists founded Comisión Femenil Mexicana Nacional.
  • Anne Koedt organized American "consciousness raising" groups.
  • Twenty-eight women founded the National Organization for Women (NOW) to function as a civil rights organization for women
  • In Italy, Rivolta Femminile formed and published a manifesto.
  • The North American Indian Women's Association and the National Black Feminist Organization were founded.
  • Eve Ensler launched the V-day movement, rising money for women’s anti-violence groups
  • Eve Ensler founds One Billion Rising to end sexual violence against women
  • Emma Watson launches HeforShe at the UN
  • Barack Obama launches the White House Task Force to Protect Students from Sexual Assault.
  • Time's Up, a movement against sexual harassment, was founded by Hollywood celebrities
  • In 1913, 50.000 women took part in a pilgrimage organized by the National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies.
  • Suffragettes started to fight for their rights, often ending up in a violent activism.
  • A delegation of women presented a petition to Parliament with 37.000 signatures demanding votes for women.
  • The first Take Back the Night march was held, followed by annual appointments.
  • The Guerrilla Girls formed in the early 1980s as a response to sexism and racism in the art world.
  • The first SlutWalk was held in response to police office's statement that "women should avoid dressing like sluts in order not to be victimized".
  • Women’s March continued to be held worldwide to support women’s rights.
  • Free the Nipple argues for women's right to show breasts in public.
  • The protest spread in different areas, such as representation of women in media, and video-games
  • The 2012 Delhi gang rape sparks protests in India and global outrage.
  • Women begin to have access to universities worldwide.
  • Enrollment to elementary schools begins to be compulsory for both sexes worldwide.
  • Women have access to primary school in different countries here it wasn’t possible before.
  • Women have access to universities in different countries here it wasn’t possible before.
  • Colleges at University Of Oxford opened admissions to women.
  • The Education Amendments became law, prohibiting discrimination based on sex in any federally funded education program.

← Back to Timeline

Feminism in the digital Era

Examples of fourth-wave feminist campaigns like Everyday Sexism, Free The Nipple, HeForShe, MeToo and YesAllWomen shows how the social networks have become a new effective way to spread and to encourage feminism protests. As can be seen in the visualization based on the data gained from Google Trend, the MeToo movement that focuses on sexual harassment and sexual assault is the most significant of them all and and continues to spread more and more everyday.
